title: Private town
text:
A private town is a town owned by a private person or a family.
History of Poland.
In the <a href="history%20of%20Poland">history of Poland</a>, private towns ("miasta prywatne") were towns within the lands owned by <a href="Magnates%20of%20Poland%20and%20Lithuania">magnates</a>, <a href="bishop">bishop</a>s, <a href="knight">knight</a>s, <a href="prince">prince</a>s, etc.
Amongst the most well-known former private magnate towns are <a href="Bia%C5%82ystok">Białystok</a>, <a href="Zamo%C5%9B%C4%87">Zamość</a>, <a href="Rzesz%C3%B3w">Rzeszów</a>, <a href="Pu%C5%82awy">Puławy</a>, <a href="Tarn%C3%B3w">Tarnów</a>, <a href="Siedlce">Siedlce</a>, <a href="Bia%C5%82a%20Podlaska">Biała Podlaska</a>, <a href="Ivano-Frankivsk">Ivano-Frankivsk</a> (Polish: "Stanisławów"), <a href="Ternopil">Ternopil</a> (Polish: "Tarnopol") and <a href="Uman">Uman</a> (Polish: "Humań"). Magnate palaces and castles can be often found in former private magnate towns. Examples include the <a href="Branicki%20Palace%2C%20Bia%C5%82ystok">Branicki Palace</a> in Białystok, the Czartoryski Palace in Puławy, the Zamoyski Palace in Zamość, the Lubomirski Castle in Rzeszów, the Radziwiłł Palace in Biała Podlaska, the Ogiński Palace in Siedlce, the Potocki Palaces in <a href="Mi%C4%99dzyrzec%20Podlaski">Międzyrzec Podlaski</a>, <a href="Tulchyn">Tulchyn</a> and <a href="Vysokaye">Vysokaye</a>, the <a href="Vyshnivets%20Palace">Wiśniowiecki Palace</a> in <a href="Vyshnivets">Vyshnivets</a>, the <a href="Zbarazh%20Castle">Zbaraski Castle</a> in <a href="Zbarazh">Zbarazh</a>.
The most known former private bishop towns include <a href="%C5%81%C3%B3d%C5%BA">Łódź</a>, <a href="Kielce">Kielce</a>, <a href="%C5%81owicz">Łowicz</a>, <a href="Pabianice">Pabianice</a> and <a href="Skierniewice">Skierniewice</a>.
